title: 107_hr1621
content: The Act may be cited as the "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act of 2001". The Arabia Mountain area in Georgia contains diverse natural, cultural, and historical resources worthy of recognition and conservation. Partnerships between public and private entities are seen as the best way to manage these resources. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain State Conservation Park protect unique ecosystems and landmarks. The Miners Creek Preserve holds evidence of early human activity. The South River in Georgia shows early human activity. Lithonia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain have historical granite mining sites. Klondike may become a National Historic District. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to preserve natural, cultural, and historical resources in the area. It supports the development of integrated cultural and historical programs in Georgia. The Act aims to implement an integrated cultural, historical, and land resource management program to protect and interpret significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." SEC. 4. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. This section establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area. Established the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in the State, consisting of certain parcels of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map depicting the boundaries is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is designated as the management entity for the heritage area. Authorities and duties of the management entity are outlined. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers diverse interests and gives priority to preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is responsible for preserving resources, encouraging local governments to adopt land use policies, conducting quarterly public meetings on the management plan, submitting an annual report on accomplishments and expenses, and allowing audits of all records related to the expenditure of funds. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must allow audits of all records related to the expenditure of Federal funds by other organizations. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, but funds from other sources can be used for authorized purposes. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, agencies, and organizations, and include an inventory of resources to be preserved, restored, managed, or maintained. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area based on the preferred concept from the feasibility study. The plan should include an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation. This program should outline actions by various entities, funding sources, and details about the management entity for approval by the Secretary. The management entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it, providing reasons for disapproval if necessary. After the initial approval of a management plan by the Secretary, the management entity must periodically review and submit recommendations for revisions to the plan for approval within 90 days. No funds from this Act can be used to implement any proposed revisions by the management entity until approved by the Secretary. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide assistance to the heritage area for the management plan. Priority is given to conservation and educational opportunities. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Act, with a 50% federal share. SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY. The Secretary's authority to grant assistance under the Act ends on September 30, 2016.
